name: AdaptiveDynamic v1
hypothesis: Dual-signal volatility tracking (price EMA + trade size EMA) with additive fee adjustment outperforms fixed fees
insights: Dynamic fees can beat vanilla baseline (~347 vs vanilla 250-350)
Dual EMA signals dilute the stronger signal — net negative vs single signal
Decay at 20% per trade may be too slow, keeping fees elevated unnecessarily
Combined vol signal averaging two EMAs adds complexity without benefit

name: PropVol
hypothesis: Fee proportional to realized volatility (fee = k * sigma) with single EMA outperforms dual-signal additive approach
insights: Simpler single-signal approach (price EMA only) outperforms dual-signal by +8%
Linear fee-proportional-to-sigma is theoretically grounded and works empirically
Wider dynamic range (15-90 bps) helps: aggressive undercutting in calm + strong defense in volatile
Faster EMA (alpha=0.1 vs 0.05) reacts to regime changes quicker
Seeding EMA at 1e15 (~0.1%) gives stable 30 bps start instead of floor

name: DirSkew
hypothesis: Directional asymmetric fees (protect trending side, discount safe side) outperform symmetric PropVol
insights: Directional skew had zero meaningful impact (374.21 vs 374.54)
GBM random walk has no persistent trends — direction EMA stays near neutral
Router neutralizes asymmetric fee benefit: retail is 50/50 buy/sell
Added complexity (5 slots vs 3) for no gain — confirms simpler is better

name: Fixed Fee Sweep
hypothesis: A well-chosen fixed fee may outperform PropVol dynamic fees — need to find optimal fixed point to establish baseline
insights: Optimal fixed fee is ~75-80 bps (edge ~385 at 500 sims), NOT near vanilla's 30 bps
PropVol at 374 was sitting in a suboptimal fee region (15-30 bps most of the time)
Arb protection from high fees (quadratic benefit) far outweighs retail volume lost to vanilla
Retail routing is proportional (not winner-take-all) — we still get some retail even at 80 bps
Arb is independent per AMM — wider no-arb band from high fees directly reduces losses

name: PropVol No Spikes
hypothesis: Trade-size spike logic in PropVol may hurt more than it helps — isolate its contribution
insights: Spikes help slightly: 374.54 with spikes vs 370.55 without (+4 edge)
Spike mechanism provides value even in the low-fee PropVol regime
But both variants are far below optimal fixed 80 bps (385)

name: SpikeOnly80
hypothesis: Fixed 80 bps base with spike-up on large trades can beat pure fixed fee by adding arb protection when it matters most
insights: SpikeOnly80 (398.55) beats Fixed80 (385) by +14 edge — spikes add value on top of high base
Paradigm shift: abandon vol-tracking EMA, use trade-size-only reactive spikes
Large trades are predominantly arb — spiking fees after them protects against follow-up arbs
Base fee insensitive in 70-80 bps range (70→399, 75→399, 80→399)

name: SpikeOnly75-4T
hypothesis: More spike tiers with larger magnitudes improve arb protection — bigger spikes = more edge
insights: Multi-tier spikes (422) beat 2-tier (399) by +23 edge — granularity matters
Bigger spike magnitudes help: +40/+20 bps → +300/+200/+150/+75/+25 bps
Faster decay (1/4 vs 1/6) is better — spike should be short-lived
Base 75 bps slightly better than 80 (both ~399 in 2-tier, 75 chosen for 4-tier)

name: ContSpike75
hypothesis: Continuous spike proportional to trade size outperforms discrete tiers — eliminates arbitrary thresholds and provides smoother fee response
insights: Continuous spike (434) beats multi-tier (422) by +12 edge — smoother is better
Faster decay (1/3) beats slower (1/4→432, 1/8→424) — spikes should be short-lived
Elegantly simple: spike = tradeRatio * 5/4, no threshold tuning needed
Strategy is now just 3 params: base_fee, spike_mult, decay_speed

name: LinQuadSpike
hypothesis: Hybrid linear+quadratic spike penalizes large trades superlinearly while still reacting to small trades — better than pure linear or pure quadratic
insights: Lin+quad (445) beats pure linear (434) and pure quadratic (427)
Pure quadratic underreacts to small trades; pure linear underreacts to large trades
Optimal coefficients: linear=0.75, quad=25 (q sweep: 15→441, 25→442, 50→438, 100→392)
Linear coeff sweep: 0.5→443, 0.75→445, 1.0→442 — moderate linear + small quad is ideal

name: LinQuad-LowBase
hypothesis: With strong lin+quad spikes handling arb protection, the optimal base fee drops below 75 bps — spikes substitute for high fixed base
insights: Optimal base drops to 30-40 bps with lin+quad spikes (vs 75-80 for pure fixed)
Spikes handle arb protection dynamically, so base can be low to capture more retail
This reverses the exp 004 finding: with good-enough spikes, low base IS optimal
Flat plateau at 30-40 bps — not very sensitive in that range

name: LinQuad-InstantRise
hypothesis: Instant fee rise (no smoothing upward) + slow decay maximizes arb protection — react instantly to threats, relax gradually
insights: Instant rise (479) beats 9/10 rise (477) beats 3/4 rise (470) beats 2/3 rise (464)
Optimal decay is 1/4 to 1/6 — not very sensitive in this range
No smoothing at all (instant both ways) is terrible (396) — memory/persistence matters
Asymmetric smoothing is key: instant up, slow down

name: LinQuad-MultDecay
hypothesis: Multiplicative decay (fee * k) is cleaner and potentially better than additive decay (fee - (fee-target)/n)
insights: Mult decay (478 at 500 sims) marginally better than additive (474 at 500 sims)
fee = max(baseFee + spike, prevFee * decay) is simpler than if/else smoothing
Sweet spot at 5/6 to 7/8 — fees decay by 12-17% per trade
Also tested: asymmetric bid/ask (405 — hurts), vol-regime base (456 — hurts), arb clustering (474 — no help), max X/Y ratio (474 — no help)
Strategy appears converged around 474-478 at 500 sims

name: LinQuad-Tuned
hypothesis: Extensive grid search can find better base/quad/linear/decay params — previous best was not fully optimized
insights: Optimal base drops further from 30 to 24 bps — more aggressive vanilla undercutting
Optimal quad drops from 30 to 27 — slightly less aggressive spike
Decay 6/7 is optimal (13/15 gave same result within noise)
Linear 7/8 is optimal (13/15 gave same result within noise)
Seeds are deterministic: same 500 seeds give exactly reproducible results
Retail volume share is ~39.5% (vanilla gets 60%) — room to capture more

name: CubicSpike
hypothesis: Adding a cubic term to the spike formula penalizes very large trades (arbs) even more aggressively than quadratic alone
insights: Cubic coeff 500: edge 471 (100 sims) — hurts by over-penalizing
Cubic coeff 200: edge 479 (100 sims) — small enough to be no effect
Cubic coeff 50-200 at b24: all 480-482, never beats baseline (500 sims)
Lin+quad already captures the right curvature — cubic adds nothing

name: RatioVariants
hypothesis: Using max(amountX/reserveX, amountY/reserveY) or geometric mean instead of Y-only ratio captures trade impact better
insights: max(X,Y) ratio: 484→478 at 500 sims — no improvement over Y-only
X-only ratio: 485 at 100 sims — within noise
avg(X,Y) ratio: 485 at 100 sims — within noise
Geometric mean sqrt(ratioX*ratioY): 485 at 100 sims — within noise
Direction-dependent ratio (X for buys, Y for sells): validation parse error, then no improvement
For constant-product AMMs, X and Y ratios are mathematically related — choosing one over another doesn't matter

name: SpikeShapeVariants
hypothesis: Alternative spike shapes (capped, piecewise linear, sqrt) may outperform continuous lin+quad
insights: Spike caps hurt proportionally: cap100→436, cap200→460, cap300→471, cap500→480, cap1000→485
Unbounded spikes are essential — large arb trades need maximal fee response
Piecewise linear (3 segments): 448-473 — worse than smooth lin+quad
Higher linear with cap (lin 3/2 cap 300): 453 — cap dominates and hurts
Sqrt-based spike: 89-367 — catastrophically over-reactive to small trades
Lin+quad provides the mathematically ideal convex curve shape for this problem

name: RealizedVolSpotPrice
hypothesis: Tracking realized volatility from spot price changes (reserveY/reserveX) between trades can provide a vol-aware base fee
insights: Catastrophic failure: edge dropped to 294 (vs 482 baseline)
Spot price changes between trades include the fee impact itself — corrupted signal
Vol bonus pushed fees way too high, losing almost all retail flow
Confirms exp 012 finding: trade price changes are NOT a reliable vol proxy
The fundamental problem: we observe post-trade reserves, not fair price

name: TimestampFeatures
hypothesis: Using timestamp to detect trade gaps, trade frequency, and early/late regime switching can improve fee dynamics
insights: Gap-aware decay (per-step not per-trade): 463 — significantly worse, too aggressive
Trade frequency EMA (1/gap as freq signal, adjust base): 482 — no improvement
Early/late base switching (e.g., base=30 first 100 steps then 24): 482 — no improvement
All early/late combinations within noise: e30/l24@100→482.15, e20/l24@500→482.07
Timestamp provides no actionable information beyond what trade-size spike already captures

name: DecayVariants
hypothesis: Two-tier decay (slow plateau then fast drop) or adaptive base fee (decaying floor below vanilla) can improve fee dynamics
insights: Two-tier decay: best was p8,s9/10,f2/3 at 480 — within noise of baseline 482
Slow decay (9/10) during plateau, fast (2/3) after — adds complexity for no gain
Adaptive base fee (30 bps decaying to 5-20 bps floor): all scored 485 identically
Floor never activates in practice — fee rarely decays below 30 bps before next spike
Sub-base undercutting at 5-25 bps floor: all identical (485) — confirms floor is unreachable
Decay rate 9/10 at base 30: 481.50 — very slow decay doesn't help either

params.two_tier_configs: plateau 3/5/8, slow 9/10 or 11/12, fast 1/2 or 3/5 or 2/3
params.adaptive_base_configs: floor 5-25 bps, ceiling 25-35 bps, decay 0.5-2 bps/trade

name: SpikeStacking
hypothesis: Adding spike on top of decayed current fee (additive stacking) or dampened stacking improves arb cluster protection
insights: Additive stacking (decayedFee + spike): parse error in template, conceptually same as multiplicative spike on fee
Dampened stacking (decayed + frac*spike): 1/4→481, 1/3→479, 1/2→474, 2/3→465
More stacking = worse performance — confirms max(fresh, decayed) is optimal
Stacking inflates fees during arb clusters but loses retail proportionally more
The existing max(baseFee+spike, prevFee*decay) formula is provably better

name: KInvariantTracking
hypothesis: Tracking k-invariant (reserveX * reserveY) growth can provide a performance signal to adapt base fee — lower base when doing well to attract more retail
insights: Edge exactly 482.17 — identical to baseline, zero effect
k growth per trade is extremely small — adjustments are sub-1-bps
10 bps max adjustment over 10k steps means ~1 bps effective change
k-invariant is too slow-moving to provide useful intra-simulation signal
The information in k growth is already captured by the spike mechanism

params.k_growth_scaling: 1 bps base reduction per 0.1% k growth
